body: I will work on a proposal for this.

issue.title: TestIdentifier methods: isTest() and isContainer()

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
TestIdentifier has these two methods: `isTest()` and `isContainer()`. As per my understanding, `isTest()` is used to identify a test case that is executed and `isContainer()` is used to identify a container of these test cases. Hence, a `@TestFactory` method is a container and not a test.

Is there anything else to the meaning of `isContainer()`? If not, these two are exactly opposite of each other and one of them can be removed.

Also, it would be useful to have another method called as `isTestFactory()`, which can be used to identify a container method. Or, is there any other way to identify a test factory method?

issue.title: Does it make sense for a TestDescriptor to be both a test and a container?

milestone.title: 5.0 M5
milestone.description: Themes: dynamic containers, test instance lifecycle management, and minor API changes.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

In [Specsy](http://specsy.org/), it's not known before executing a test whether its TestDescriptor has children or not. The nested tests are discovered dynamically while the test is executed. This holds true also for the top-level test, which is the test class itself. Thus conceptually all TestDescriptors are both tests and containers. This caused a problem with IntelliJ IDEA test results (see [this comment](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-148288#comment=27-1518123) and [its reply](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-148288#comment=27-1518474)) and I had to do [a workaround](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-148288#comment=27-1518757).

## Deliverables

This issue should be not closed until the following issues have been resolved.

- [ ] What does JUnit mean by the concepts of "test" and "container"?
- [ ] How should IDEs and other tools change their behavior based on those variables?
   - If they shouldn't change behavior, then why do the variables exist?
- [ ] What about the case of isTest()=false and isContainer()=false?
- [ ] What about defining them dynamically based on whether there are children? (I tried it. IntelliJ IDEA doesn't notice that the values change during test execution.)
- [ ] Would it be possible to remove both concepts, and just check whether a TestDescriptor has children?

body:
Team decision:

- Remove `isContainer()` from `TestDescriptor` and `TestIdentifier` (maybe deprecate it as a first step).
- Add `willRegisterTests()` (or a better name) to `TestDescriptor` and `TestIdentifier`.
- Remove `hasTests()` from `TestDescriptor` (deprecate first)
- Change pruning to use `isTest() || willRegisterTests()`.

This not being _in progress_ I started looking into it. I have done an initial investigation on how to proceed with this and I have come up with these points and questions.

The to be deprecated methods are used in quite a few places and we will have to express the calling code's intent without using these methods.

From my study of this issue and its related ones, I came to these points on how to do the expression. I would appreciate your opinion and comments on them.

* Do not use the notion of container to distinguish `Identifiers, Descriptors`.
  * This then begs the question how to express eg `jupiter.engine.DisabledTests` 
   which uses `ExecutionEventRecorder::getContainerSkippedCount` or tests using
  `platform.engine.test.event.ExecutionEventConditions::container`

* When we need to disregard Descriptors or Identifiers that in essense do no 
  represent any testing the we will use the `isTest() || [will]RegistersTests()`

Not related with how to express the callers intent, these also require consideration:
* From looking into the code I think `willRegisterTests` is not a good name 
  because it implies that this `Identifier, Descriptor` will do the registration
  in the future but we do need to check this even after we have registered tests
  so this could become misleading. `registersTests()` seems better to me
* This leads in many cases to simply replace the `isContainer()` with 
  `registersTests()` which still implies the notion/concept of a container.

First, thank you @gaganis for your inspection, thoughts and summary regarding this issue. Especially, your last bullet point hits the nail on its head: the concept of having containers and tests is valid and will remain. It makes no sense to rename (to a worse name) and keep the concept.

I'm preparing a PR at the moment, that takes your considerations into account and tries to tackle both:

- is test = is not container ... an identifier/descriptor is a test or it is a container; never both or none.
- demote (hide) TestDescriptor.hasTests() from API

issue.title: Redesign isTest() and isContainer() in TestDescriptor

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

body:
Hi guys,

I have not looked into PR #720 , but... I _can_ shed some light on the original concepts and rationale in play here.

> is test = is not container ... an identifier/descriptor is a test or it is a container; never both or none.

For starters, I do not agree with the above assumption that "an identifier/descriptor is never both a test and a container".

Here are some things to keep in mind:

1. Do **not** look at JUnit Jupiter when considering whether it makes sense for a something to be both a test and a container.
    - JUnit Jupiter is merely _one_ implementation of a `TestEngine`: it is **not** the guiding light for how all test engines must work.
1. Consider that a different testing framework running on the JUnit Platform might have a need for a node in the test tree that is simultaneously a test **and** a container.
    - In fact, I believe that the Specsy framework does exactly that. If it's not Specsy, it's something else I have seen.

In summary, for this particular feature we have to focus on the _big picture_, the JUnit Platform. 

With that in mind, I believe we need the following possible states for a node -- where being neither a container nor a test is not an option.

1. is a container
1. is a test
1. is a container and a test

Perhaps an enum would best address this topic.
